    <item>
      <title> The New Old Age: America at Home: Grandparents in the Attic, Children in the Basement</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/17/health/multigenerational-shared-households.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/17/health/multigenerational-shared-households.html</guid>
      <atom:link href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/17/health/multigenerational-shared-households.html?partner=rss&emc=rss" rel="standout"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/20/science/20SCI-SPAN/20SCI-SPAN-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Susan Yarbrough, right, lives with her mother, Betsy Yarbrough, and their dog, Maddie, in Johns Creek, Ga. The Yarbroughs share the house and its duties, part of a nationwide uptick in shared and multigenerational households.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Kevin D. Liles for The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>Multigenerational and shared housing arrangements are on the rise, reversing a decades-long trend.</description>
      <dc:creator>PAULA SPAN</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 13:35:40 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Families and Family Life</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Population</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Recession and Depression</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Elderly</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Elder Care</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Real Estate and Housing (Residential)</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Diplomats in Cuba Suffered Brain Injuries. Experts Still Don’t Know Why.</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/15/health/cuba-diplomats-attack-concussions.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/15/health/cuba-diplomats-attack-concussions.html</guid>
      <atom:link href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/15/health/cuba-diplomats-attack-concussions.html?partner=rss&emc=rss" rel="standout"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/17/science/17CUBA-ATTACK/16CUBA-ATTACK-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>The United States Embassy in Havana. Several American diplomats in Cuba reported mysterious ailments in 2016 after hearing unusual noises. Medical experts now say the officials have injuries resembling concussions.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Meridith Kohut for The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>After examining 21 American diplomats said to have been victims of a mysterious “attack” in Havana, medical experts found concussion-like damage but no obvious causes.</description>
      <dc:creator>GINA KOLATA</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 15 Feb 2018 23:32:07 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Cuba</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">United States International Relations</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Brain</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Concussions</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Sonar</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Havana (Cuba)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">JAMA (Journal of American Medical Assn)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">State Department</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">University of Pennsylvania</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>The Flu Vaccine Is Working Better Than Expected, C.D.C. Finds</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/15/health/flu-vaccine-effectiveness.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/15/health/flu-vaccine-effectiveness.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/15/health/flu-vaccine-effectiveness.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/16/science/16FLU1/16FLU1-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Nurse Nicole Simpson administering a flu shot at the Salvation Army in Atlanta earlier this month. This season’s vaccine is more effective than expected, officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced Thursday.</media:description>
      <media:credit>David Goldman/Associated Press</media:credit>
      <description>A preliminary analysis finds the vaccine 25 percent effective against this year’s dangerous H3N2 strain, and twice as effective in children.</description>
      <dc:creator>DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 00:11:33 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Vaccination and Immunization</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Influenza</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Azar, Alex M II</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>In Allergy Bullying, Food Can Hurt</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/15/well/family/in-allergy-bullying-food-can-hurt.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/15/well/family/in-allergy-bullying-food-can-hurt.html</guid>
      <atom:link href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/15/well/family/in-allergy-bullying-food-can-hurt.html?partner=rss&emc=rss" rel="standout"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/15/well/family/well-peanuts/well-peanuts-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description/>
      <media:credit>iStock</media:credit>
      <description>An attack with allergens shown in a “Peter Rabbit” scene mirrors real-life threats to kids’ health, parents say.</description>
      <dc:creator>RONI CARYN RABIN</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 15 Feb 2018 22:30:41 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Allergies</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Children and Childhood</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Anaphylactic Shock</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Peanuts</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Bullies</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Parenting</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Ask Well: Do I Get Enough Vitamin D in the Winter?</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/16/well/live/do-i-get-enough-vitamin-d-in-the-winter.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/16/well/live/do-i-get-enough-vitamin-d-in-the-winter.html</guid>
      <atom:link href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/16/well/live/do-i-get-enough-vitamin-d-in-the-winter.html?partner=rss&emc=rss" rel="standout"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/20/well/ask-winter-snow/ask-winter-snow-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description/>
      <media:credit>Dan Balilty for The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>In higher-latitude cities like Boston, inadequate UVB limits vitamin D synthesis for at least a few months during the winter.</description>
      <dc:creator>ALICE CALLAHAN</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 11:00:15 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Vitamins</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Vitamin D</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Seasons and Months</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Sunlight</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Protective Clothing and Gear</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Concussions Can Be Detected With New Blood Test Approved by F.D.A.</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/14/health/concussion-fda-bloodtest.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/14/health/concussion-fda-bloodtest.html</guid>
      <atom:link href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/14/health/concussion-fda-bloodtest.html?partner=rss&emc=rss" rel="standout"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/15/science/15BRAIN/15BRAIN-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Samples in a cold storage area at Banyan Biomarkers in San Diego. The company's blood test to detect concussions quickly after injuries was approved by the F.D.A. on Wednesday.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Denis Poroy/Associated Press</media:credit>
      <description>The test may be able to quickly identify people with suspected brain injuries that could be widely used by the Pentagon and in sports.</description>
      <dc:creator>SHEILA KAPLAN and KEN BELSON</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 15 Feb 2018 17:51:49 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Concussions</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Tests (Medical)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Brain</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Traumatic Brain Injury</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">United States Defense and Military Forces</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Sports Injuries</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Defense Department</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Food and Drug Administration</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>New York Will Investigate Reports of Gay Men Denied Insurance</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/14/health/insurance-discrimination-gay-prep.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/14/health/insurance-discrimination-gay-prep.html</guid>
      <atom:link href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/14/health/insurance-discrimination-gay-prep.html?partner=rss&emc=rss" rel="standout"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/15/science/15PREPprint/15PREP-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>A bottle of Truvada at a health center in Manhattan. New York’s insurance regulators will investigate whether companies denied policies to gay men after learning they took the drug to prevent infection with H.I.V.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>Denying men life or disability policies because they take drugs to prevent H.I.V. is discriminatory and may trigger penalties.</description>
      <dc:creator>DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 15 Feb 2018 00:32:24 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Discrimination</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Homosexuality and Bisexuality</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Truvada (Drug)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Insurance</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">GLBTQ Legal Advocates and Defenders (GLAD)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">New York Times</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">New York State</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Phys Ed: A Before-School Exercise Program May Help Children Thrive</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/14/well/move/a-before-school-exercise-program-may-help-children-thrive.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/14/well/move/a-before-school-exercise-program-may-help-children-thrive.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/14/well/move/a-before-school-exercise-program-may-help-children-thrive.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/20/well/physed-kids-exercise/physed-kids-exercise-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>A one-hour, before-school exercise program does seem likely to improve young people’s health and happiness.</media:description>
      <media:credit>iStock</media:credit>
      <description>The BOKS program, consisting of an hour of running, calisthenics and rousing group games, made children feel happier and more energetic.</description>
      <dc:creator>GRETCHEN REYNOLDS</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 15 Feb 2018 16:11:27 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Exercise</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Education (K-12)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Children and Childhood</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Games</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Research</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Happiness</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Obesity</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Parenting</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Youth</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Man Crashes Truck Into New Jersey Planned Parenthood, Injuring 3, Police Say</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/17/nyregion/truck-attack-planned-parenthood.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/17/nyregion/truck-attack-planned-parenthood.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/17/nyregion/truck-attack-planned-parenthood.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/18/autossell/18xp-plannedparenthood/18xp-plannedparenthood-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Marckles Alcius</media:description>
      <media:credit>Essex County Jail</media:credit>
      <description>A suspect was charged after three people, including a pregnant woman, sustained minor injuries in the crash. The authorities would not comment on a motive.</description>
      <dc:creator>JACEY FORTIN</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 20:03:15 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Alcius, Marckles</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Planned Parenthood Federation of America</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">East Orange (NJ)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Assaults</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Traffic Accidents and Safety</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Still Talking After All These Years</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/17/style/american-psychoanalytic-association-donald-trump.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/17/style/american-psychoanalytic-association-donald-trump.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/17/style/american-psychoanalytic-association-donald-trump.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/18/fashion/18PSYCHOANALYSTS/merlin_133938884_ad2817ad-ea8c-4f43-af2b-69643e8f0c7c-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description/>
      <media:credit>Shonagh Rae</media:credit>
      <description>At the annual meeting of the American Psychoanalytic Association, the seminars covered the quantum hologram (huh?) and President Trump.</description>
      <dc:creator>PENELOPE GREEN</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 11:00:01 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Psychology and Psychologists</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Narcissism</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">American Psychoanalytic Assn</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Freud, Sigmund</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Checking Facts and Falsehoods About Gun Violence and Mental Illness After Parkland Shooting</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/16/us/politics/fact-check-parkland-gun-violence-mental-illness.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/16/us/politics/fact-check-parkland-gun-violence-mental-illness.html</guid>
      <atom:link href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/16/us/politics/fact-check-parkland-gun-violence-mental-illness.html?partner=rss&emc=rss" rel="standout"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/18/us/politics/18cruz-p/17dc-factcheck-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Nikolas Cruz, the man suspected of killing 17 people at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, in court in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. on Thursday.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Pool photo by Susan Stocker</media:credit>
      <description>Paul Ryan, Bernie Sanders and others stated facts and falsehoods in the wake of the Parkland Shooting.</description>
      <dc:creator>LINDA QIU and JUSTIN BANK</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 05:47:01 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Gun Control</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">School Shootings and Armed Attacks</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Parkland (Fla)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Huckabee, Mike</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Ryan, Paul D Jr</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Sanders, Bernard</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Patricia Frustaci, 63, Dies; Septuplets Put Her in Spotlight</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/16/obituaries/patricia-frustaci-63-dies-septuplets-put-her-in-spotlight.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/16/obituaries/patricia-frustaci-63-dies-septuplets-put-her-in-spotlight.html</guid>
      <atom:link href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/16/obituaries/patricia-frustaci-63-dies-septuplets-put-her-in-spotlight.html?partner=rss&emc=rss" rel="standout"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/18/obituaries/18frustaci1/16frustaci1-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Patricia Frustaci with her husband, Sam, and their children in 1988: from left, Stephen, Patricia, Joseph and Richard.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Douglas C. Pizac/Associated Press</media:credit>
      <description>Her multiple births set a record in 1985, and they led to a medical ordeal, early deaths, a lawsuit and a flood of media attention.</description>
      <dc:creator>DANIEL E. SLOTNIK</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 20:44:58 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Frustaci, Patricia</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Deaths (Obituaries)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Multiple Births</category>

      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Fertility Drugs</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Global Health: Lassa Fever Erupts in Nigeria</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/16/health/lassa-fever-nigeria.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/16/health/lassa-fever-nigeria.html</guid>
      <atom:link href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/16/health/lassa-fever-nigeria.html?partner=rss&emc=rss" rel="standout"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/20/science/20GLOBAL/20GLOBAL-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>A pile of garri, a staple food in Nigeria, in a shop in Lagos. The country is fighting an outbreak of Lassa virus, which is transmitted in rodent feces and urine and can contaminate foods like garri.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images</media:credit>
      <description>The disease, carried by rodents, is sometimes mild but can lead to hemorrhagic fever and death. W.H.O. has sent additional staff to help contain the outbreak.</description>
      <dc:creator>DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 19:15:08 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Lassa Fever</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Rodents</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Epidemics</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Protective Clothing and Gear</category>

    <item>
      <title>He Took a Drug to Prevent AIDS. Then He Couldn’t Get Disability Insurance.</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/12/health/truvada-hiv-insurance.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/12/health/truvada-hiv-insurance.html</guid>
      <atom:link href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/12/health/truvada-hiv-insurance.html?partner=rss&emc=rss" rel="standout"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/13/science/00AIDS/00AIDS-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>When Dr. Philip Cheng, a urologist in Boston, applied for disability insurance, he was given only short-term coverage. His broker said it was because Dr. Cheng took Truvada to prevent H.I.V. infection.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>Insurers have denied life and disability coverage to men taking Truvada to prevent H.I.V. infection, say gay rights advocates and medical experts.</description>
      <dc:creator>DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 15 Feb 2018 00:47:05 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Life Insurance</category>

    <item>
      <title>Even Australia’s Medical Marijuana Poster Boy Can’t Get the Drug</title>
      <link>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/11/world/australia/medical-marijuana-cannabis-lindsay-carter.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/11/world/australia/medical-marijuana-cannabis-lindsay-carter.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/11/world/australia/medical-marijuana-cannabis-lindsay-carter.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/12/world/00oz-cannabis-1/00oz-cannabis-1-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Lindsay Carter, 19, at home with his mother during a “focal seizure,” which temporarily blocks his ability to speak or comprehend. Medical marijuana has helped him manage his epilepsy, but the drug is difficult to obtain even though it is legal.</media:description>
      <media:credit>David Maurice Smith for The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>Though legal in Australia, medical marijuana is difficult to obtain. One teenager, Lindsay Carter, has become the face of the issue.</description>
      <dc:creator>TACEY RYCHTER</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Mon, 12 Feb 2018 03:20:51 GMT</pubDate>
